oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: James House and Janie Fricke Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Janie Fricke (performer), conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: James House; Biff Collie; Janie Fricke
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) James House 'Don't Quit Me Now' radio spot -- (00:14) 'Its Cruel' by House is discussed -- (00:48) House recalls how he began recording in his room and being self taught -- (01:25)' Hard Times for a Honest Man,' House's new single is discussed -- (02:04) The history of House growing up is told and being underage playing in clubs -- (02:55) 'Under the Harvest Moon' is compared to poem inspiration -- (03:48) House retells how he broke his arm and switched to left handed guitars -- (04:12) 'Never Until now' is briefly discussed -- (4:43) House retells how he came to being signed under MCA Records -- (05:47) 'Oh What A Thrill' style selection is discussed -- (06:19) Biff Collie asks what advice House has had in Nashville and House refers to Don Schlitz -- (06:58) House refers to 'Lucinda' cord structure and screening material -- House describes giving up on a song previous to starting 'That'll Be the Last Thang' -- (08:30) Hose speaks of the exhaustive schedule -- (08:51) House speaks of radio appreciation dates and going to England -- (09:30) House's families musical connections are addressed -- (10:09) House speaks of cooperation with Walt Aldridge on 'Call It in the Air' -- (10:39) House's 'Born Ready' is discussed -- (11:15) House's exciting experience of signing with a label -- (11:48) House discusses favorite singers -- (12:10) House addresses his handling of recognition and profitability of music -- (13:34) Closing Remarks between Collie and House -- (13:47) 'Love is One of Those Words' is discussed between Collie and Janie Fricke -- (14:13) Fricke touches on 'Give Em My Number' and the multiple songs brought into pre-production -- (15:41) Fricke discusses the pageantry of being a show person -- (16:12) Fricke discusses how her husband wrote 'The Last Thing That I Didn't Do' while in the car -- (16:55) Collie discusses with Fricke where she lived -- (17:15) 'Walking on the Moon' is briefly discussed -- (17:45) Fricke discusses the origin of her beginning work in Nashville -- (18:40) 'Feeling is Believing' by House is described as "against her style" -- (19:00) 'I Can't Help the Way I Don't Feel' is described as sad and repetitive -- (19:19) Fricke talks about hand-painted clothing line -- (20:42) 'No Ordinary Memory' and what songs Fricke brought to her producer -- 'One of Those Things' is described as a strong delivery -- (21:58) Fricke's dreams as a child and teaching is discussed -- (23:28) How 'My Old Friend the Blues' by Fricke was found and the album release process -- (24:44) Fricke discusses growing up on a farm and learning to love singing through church services -- (25:52) Collie asks about Fricke's experience with fear -- (27:40) Fricke's siblings are discussed -- (28:03) Fricke's musical knowledge is discussed -- (28:32) Fricke discusses dropping out of school for music and her learning process -- (32:04) Fricke's musical inspiration and sheet music is discussed -- (33:02) Fricke describes her musical history with her sister -- (33:30) Where Fricke's love of music is talked about through a story of her youth and her parents -- (35:58) Fricke discusses the uncertainty of children -- (37:32) Fricke says that she never thought she would become a recording artist -- (39:16) Fricke recalls seeing going on the road as a foreign concept -- (40:00) Fricke discusses meeting and dating and being proposed to by Randy Jackson -- (42:10) Fricke speaks about how she toured in Europe with Randy Jackson -- (43:02) Fricke speaks about her first producer and records -- (43:47) 'Always Have, Always Will" is briefly discussed -- (44:06) 'Love Me' is briefly discussed -- (44:22) Fricke brings up her time in Memphis -- (45:20) Fricke and Charley Pride's relationship is discussed -- (45:47) 'He's a Heartache' is described as "high energy" -- (46:10) 'Let's Stop Talkin' Bout It' is briefly addressed -- 'Please Help Me I'm Fallin'' is described as Fricke's favorite -- (46:38) 'She's Single Again' called a "story telling song" -- (46:58) 'Tell Me A Lie' by Fricke is describe -- (47:25) Fricke describes not having her own band -- (47:40) Fricke describes her band and how the came to be -- (48:11) Fricke's hobbies are discusses as well as pets -- (49:05) Collie inquires about Fricke's value of home -- (50:01) Fricke addresses what relationship she has with her parents -- (51:07) Fricke addresses her thoughts on the future
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: House, James; Collie, Biff; Fricke, Janie;
